awd_titl_txt: CAREER: CS-CLIMATE: Fostering Collaborative Dialogue for Rigorous Learning and Diverse Student Retention in Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
A rich body of evidence suggests that collaborative learning holds many benefits for computer science students, yet there is growing recognition that neither collaborative learning itself, nor the innovative curricula in which it may be situated, are "magic bullets" for solving computing's pipeline problem. In contrast to being a one-size-fits-all solution, collaborative learning is highly dependent upon characteristics of the collaborators and on fine-grained interactions. The overarching research question of this project is: Can we identify and support the facets of collaborative dialogue that are particularly effective for fostering learning, sense of identity, motivation, and continued engagement for diverse computer science learners?

The project investigates this question in three activities. Firstly, a rich set of computer science collaborative learning data will be collected, leveraging the ASCEND learning environment, which supports remote collaboration with textual natural language dialogue, synchronized code editing, and integrated repository control for two or more collaborators. Data will be collected at three partnering institutions: North Carolina State University, Meredith College (an all-women's institution), and Florida A&M University (a minority-serving university with 90% African American enrollment), and will include student characteristics of gender, race/ethnicity, personality profile, and achievement goal orientation, as well as measures of outcomes such as learning, sense of computing identity, motivation, and engagement.  Secondly, the project will examine the fine-grained facets of collaborative dialogue that are particularly effective for diverse computer science learners, in order to create fine-grained, theoretically informed models that capture collaborative dialogue and problem solving phenomena associated with learning, identity development, motivation, and engagement.  Thirdly, the project will implement and evaluate evidence-based pedagogical support for fostering effective collaborative dialogue. 

It is expected that the resulting pedagogical support will significantly improve learning, sense of identity, motivation, and continued engagement for students overall, and for women and African American students in particular. In addition, the project will produce fine-grained sequential analyses and rich qualitative findings that further the state of knowledge about how diverse students learn computing.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of the CS-CLIMATE project was to build fine-grained models of collaborative dialogue for computer science learning, with particular emphasis on underrepresented groups in computing: women and African American students. These models served as the basis for a grounded theory of collaborative learning and accompanying evidence-based pedagogical innovations for supporting diverse students. The project made significant contributions in the following areas:

1) We iteratively designed, developed, and refined an innovative set of pedagogical strategies that were implemented with more than 1500 novice programming learners over the course of the project. These strategies are novel to CS education and produced promising results to improve learning outcomes and student engagement in coding. Also, one of the central goals of the project was to foster effective collaboration for underrepresented groups in computing, and the project has put a special focus on increasing diversity in tech fields, which has the potential to transform the creation of new technologies in the future.

2) We developed two collaborative coding tools: The project first started with the development of an Eclipse plug-in that would allow learners to synchronously work on coding problems. Eclipse was one of the most commonly used integrated development environments (IDEs) in programming education. The plug-in would connect two learners to one another and allow them to take turns while working on a shared programming problem. Later, our collaborative tool development efforts evolved from a static coding environment to an adaptive environment, building an extension on the VS Code IDE. The extension, known as the Dialogue-Enabled Coding Knowledge Support (DECKS), is able to listen to students’ dialogue in real time as they collaborate on code, and can provide documentation and syntax support based on the learners’ dialogue. The DECKS extension is also compatible with the LiveShare extension, which supports students’ remote collaboration, allowing them to work together from whatever location they may be in real time. 

3) The project investigated different ways of analyzing student interactions and providing adaptive support. For example, we investigated how adapting to students’ expressions of uncertainty can help improve the quality of students’ code and the quality of their collaborations. We identified some best practices for developers wishing to design adaptive technology to support student pairs during expressions of uncertainty. These best practices included managing students’ expectations about this kind of technology, leveraging computer science students’ familiarity with concepts related to adaptive support, considering the language used in the textual prompts, and providing validation feedback as well as uncertainty feedback. Providing this kind of tailored support for learners with different needs is known as adaptive scaffolding, and there is growing research interest in developing intelligent learning environments that can provide such support.

4) We have disseminated research findings from the CS Climate project with scholars and practitioners through numerous publications, presentations, and workshops. To date the findings of the project have been reported in 2 journal articles, 18 conference papers, and 1 workshop paper. Findings from this set of published work will guide future research and development on engaging, effective curricular strategies for computer science education.
